global.name: Transport Individuals 360 Immersive Activity
global.description:
Complete the following activity on procedures for transporting a client.

This activity utilises 360 media. You can click/drag or touch/swipe to look around and interact with hotspots that reveal extra information, questions or media. Use this activity to explore spaces or processes as if you were there in person.

For an enhanced immersive experience, open this activity on a VR headset to explore in Virtual Reality.

scenes.name: Let's meet our client
scenes.description:
The Scenario

The Support Services Supervisor has advised that our patient needs to be transported to Rehab centre for an appointment with the physio at 10am sharp.

The physio has requested that the patient be sent in a wheelchair.

The Health Services Assistant will facilitate the patient transport.

specific.targetDesc: Next
Haile has a physio appointment on the ground floor at 10am and must be transported there.
Duncan, the Health Services Assistant, will be assisting with transport of the client.
Julia, the Support Services Supervisor, has tasked the HSA with assisting the client. The supervisor will brief the HSA on the patient details.

questionDetails.quizQuestion: Are you allowed to perform any duties outside of your job role while transporting patients?
questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: When you are transporting clients, you must not perform any duties that are not part of your job role. If a client asks you to do something that is not part of your responsibilities, you must tell the client you will ask the nurse/supervisor to provide the help the client wants.

answers.text: Yes, but use your best judgement.
Yes, but only if asked by your supervisor.

specific.targetDesc:
Communication with clients and staff

When you have to transport a client, you must find out:

  • What time to transport
  • Who to transport
  • Where to transport from and to
  • how to transport
  • what equipment you need to use.

Staff caring for the client can confirm this information.

scenes.name: Client Handover
scenes.description:
The Scenario

To prepare for the safe transportation of a client, you should always:

  • Confirm the details of the transportation tasks with staff and patient
  • Introduce yourself and explain where you are going and what you will be doing
  • Ensure you have consent from patient
  • Allow the patient to ask questions

specific.targetDesc: Next

To prepare for the safe transportation of a client, you should always:

  • understand the client's individual needs
  • know what transport options are available
  • prepare the environment including:
    • check the route you will be taking, noting any potential dangers
    • ensure you have access, such as ramps, rails, elevators and emergency exits, etcetera.
    • ensure the building has suitable entrance and exit points

questionDetails.quizQuestion: Does the client have a right to refuse to be transported?
questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: The client can refuse to be transported. If this occurs, it is up to the care staff to discuss this with the client, identity what the client's concerns are and address the problem.

scenes.name: Checking your equipment
scenes.description:
Transporting equipment

To prevent the risk of injury to the client, or you, check that the required equipment is in good working order.
The Health Services Assistant locates the wheelchair from the stored location.

After determining the size is appropriate for the client, they unfold it, test the tyre pressure, unlock brakes and lift the footplates before attempting to move the client.

specific.targetDesc: Next
When using a wheelchair to transport a client, make sure you have selected is the correct size and the client is within the weight limit for the selected wheelchair.
Check the tyres for low pressure or damage.
Brakes must always be applied when wheelchair is stationary and you are not holding the chair.

questionDetails.quizQuestion: When using a wheelchair to transport a client, what is the first safety check you must perform?
questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: The first safety check is to determine that the wheelchair you have selected for the client is of the correct size and that the client's weight is within the supported weight limit range for the wheelchair.

answers.text: A pressure and puncture test for the wheels.
The wheelchair is the appropriate size and can support the client's weight.
The wheelchair footplates can be lifted and folded.

specific.targetDesc: Check that all parts are secure, and nothing is broken.

scenes.name: Dignity, privacy and comfort
scenes.description: You should always protect the dignity and privacy of the client. Make sure that the client is comfortable and is fully dressed or covered.Ensure that client is warm enough. If you need to take the client outside, first check the weather. Then, if you need to, bring extra blankets, an umbrella and/or a hat to protect the client.

specific.targetDesc: Next

Always ensure the client is comfortable and is fully dressed or covered.

When using a wheelchair, dress the client in a gown, and put a small sheet or blanket to cover the client's legs.
Have a blanket to cover for comfort and dignity when transporting.

scenes.name: Before transport
scenes.description:
Before transport

The HSA (Duncan) wheels the wheelchair over to the patient’s bed, talks to the patient and explains he will be assisting with moving her to the rehab/Allied Health section.

He assists her out of the hospital bed, asks her to move her legs so they reach the floor, guides her to take short steps back towards the wheelchair and helps her move into the seat, while holding her arm.

specific.targetDesc: Next

The HSA (Duncan) wheels the wheelchair over to the patient’s bed, talks to the patient and explains he will be assisting with moving her to the rehab/Allied Health section.

He assists her out of the hospital bed, asks her to move her legs so they reach the floor, guides her to take short steps back towards the wheelchair and helps her move into the seat, while holding her arm.

Explain to the client what you will be doing.

Ensure you have consent to begin and allow the client to ask questions.
The brakes must be on when the client is getting on or off the wheelchair.

questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: This is general question feedback on what is the correct answer and why.

scenes.name: Moving the client
scenes.description:
Transporting the client should always follow the organisation's policies and procedures.

Check your organisation's policy about using lap belts, and secure the client with the app belt if it is required.

Ensure that the footrests are locked in and the client’s feet are on the footrests before moving the wheelchair.

specific.targetDesc: Next

Transporting the client should always follow the organisation's policies and procedures.

Check your organisation's policy about using lap belts, and secure the client with the app belt if it is required.

Ensure that the footrests are locked in and the client’s feet are on the footrests before moving the wheelchair.
When the wheelchair is moving, the footrests must be locked in position, and the client's feet on the footplates.

questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: This is general question feedback on what is the correct answer and why.

scenes.name: During transport
scenes.description:
Movement of clients

Moving through a busy hospital or facility requires skill, and care needs to be taken to ensure the safety of the client. The safety of the client is your priority when moving the client from one area to the other.

specific.targetDesc: Hotspot description

Movement of clients

Moving through a busy hospital or facility requires skill, and care needs to be taken to ensure the safety of the client. The safety of the client is your priority when moving the client from one area to the other.

Watch for obstructions when in motion look for:

  • protrusions that could injure the client or damage the chair
  • obstructions that could tip the chair forwards (holes) or sideways
  • watch for swinging doors
  • travel at controlled speed, no more than walking pace.

scenes.name: Approaching elevators
scenes.description:
Approaching elevators

The HSA worker approaches the lift, and ensures he is standing in the correct position to the side of the lift, with the wheelchair parallel with the wall.

specific.targetDesc:
Approaching elevators

The HSA worker approaches the lift, and ensures he is standing in the correct position to the side of the lift, with the wheelchair parallel with the wall.

Wait at the side of lift doors -to allow anyone or equipment exiting safely.
Next

scenes.name: Elevator Procedure
scenes.description:
Elevator Proceedure

When using an elevator, always let the person who is exiting the elevator out first.

If the person exiting the elevator is a staff member, they will hold the door open for your client to allow unobstructed access to the elevator entryway.

When it is clear, enter an elevator in reverse, to allow for a smooth exit at your desired floor.  When exiting the elevator, look both ways before moving.

specific.targetDesc:
Elevator Proceedure

When using an elevator, always let the person who is exiting the elevator out first.

If the person exiting the elevator is a staff member, they will hold the door open for your client to allow unobstructed access to the elevator entryway.

When it is clear, enter an elevator in reverse, to allow for a smooth exit at your desired floor.  When exiting the elevator, look both ways before moving.
When entering an elevator, reverse in so you can see when doors open at your desired floor.
Next

scenes.name: Arrival at destination
scenes.description:
Arrival and Handover

We arrive and begin the handover with the recieving staff member. Details of the patient are communicated, and contact details are provided by the HSA.

The proceedure is as follows:

  • Confirm client arrival with relevant personnel at destination
  • Check if your required to wait /or give extension number to return for pick up if needed
  • handover client records and report any client events during transport

If you are leaving the client and returning later, leave your contact details with the staff members who will be looking after the client in your absence.

specific.targetDesc:
Arrival and Handover

We arrive and begin the handover with the recieving staff member. Details of the patient are communicated, and contact details are provided by the HSA.

The proceedure is as follows:

  • Confirm client arrival with relevant personnel at destination
  • Check if your required to wait /or give extension number to return for pick up if needed
  • handover client records and report any client events during transport

If you are leaving the client and returning later, leave your contact details with the staff members who will be looking after the client in your absence.

Bec, the physiotherapist, is the recieving staff member.

When you arrive with the client, always introduce the client and tell the recieving staff why the client is there. Healthcare staff will be responsible for giving information to the right person to ensure the client receives appropriate attention on arrival.
Some clients may need you to stay with them at all times. Therefore, you would need to stay in the facility until you return with the client or are relieved by another staff member.

questionDetails.quizQuestion: Are you required to leave contact details with the receiving staff member if leaving the client
questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: The HSA should always provide a contact method to the receiving staff member, such as their extension number, to return for pick up if needed.

answers.text: No, the receiving staff member will take over the responsibility.
Yes, always provide a contact method.
No, the Support Services Supervisor is responsible for the safe return of the client.

specific.targetDesc: Next

scenes.name: Preparing the client
scenes.description:
Preparing the client

The HSA assists the client by adjusting the bed to the correct height, removes blanket, then guiding her feet off the footplates, and moving the footplates to the side.

He then assists the client to stand up and directing and instructing her towards a seated position on the hospital bed, asking the client if they are ok to swing legs onto the bed.

The HSA Adjusts the back rest on the hospital bed, while asking the client to say 'when', when they are happy with the backrest angle and then places the blanket on the client.

specific.targetDesc:
The HSA assists the client by adjusting the bed to the correct height, removes blanket, then guiding her feet off the footplates, and moving the footplates to the side.

He then assists the client to stand up and directing and instructing her towards a seated position on the hospital bed, asking the client if they are ok to swing legs onto the bed.

The HSA Adjusts the back rest on the hospital bed, while asking the client to say 'when', when they are happy with the backrest angle and then places the blanket on the client.

When the client is getting off the wheelchair, undo the lap belt (if used), then if the client needs assistance, help then to lift their feet off the footplate, one at a time.

Carefully fold up and swing the footplate away from the client's legs to prevent an injury to the client.
Next

questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: This is general question feedback on what is the correct answer and why.

scenes.name: Client Transport complete
scenes.description:
Client Transport complete

The HSA says goodbye to the client and wishes her well, while taking the wheelchair back to the ward.

After transportation return equipment as per the organisation's procedures and complete client reporting requirements as required.

specific.targetDesc:
The HSA says goodbye to the client and wishes her well, while taking the wheelchair back to the ward.

After transportation return equipment as per the organisation's procedures and complete client reporting requirements as required.

All equipment should be cleaned and then returned to the relevant storage areas.

At all times, check the equipment is in good working order before storing it back in the correct area. If equipment needs maintenance or repair, always separate it, label it and report it.

questionDetails.quizQuestion: Why is it so important to clean any equipment used in patient transport?
questionDetails.generalAnswerFeedback: All answers are correct. You should complete cleaning in accordance with your organisation's policies to control the spread of infection and prevent any cross-contamination.

specific.targetDesc: Finish Scenario
